title: Cat. 7  Madame Matisse with Her Fan, 1906
publication_title: Matisse Paintings, Works on Paper, Sculpture, and Textiles at the Art Institute of Chicago
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section tombstone" id="tombstone">Madame Matisse with Her Fan  
Paris, 1906  
Pen and black ink over graphite on cream wove paper; 49.4 × 31.2 cm (19 1/8 × 12 in.)  
Signed: Henri-Matisse (lower right, in pen and black ink)  
The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Dorothy Braude Edinburg to the Harry B. and Bessie K. Braude Memorial Collection, 1998.709

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section technical_report" id="technical_report">Henri Matisse used multiple sizes of dip pens to achieve variety of line quality in this drawing of his wife. The artist drew the outlines, major contours, and most of the details using a medium-width pen-and-ink line. He used a wider pen to embellish the kimono with dark, densely spaced pen strokes (see fig. 7.1) and to shade beneath the sitter’s chair. He shaded the eyes and nose with the finest lines, using a narrow, pointed pen (see fig. 7.2). Parallel hatching and a running line were used to shade around the figure and help establish her volume in space. The drawing is composed primarily of short pen strokes due to the limited amount of ink a dip pen can hold. Matisse selected a smooth, well-sized, cream-colored paper well suited to pen-and-ink work for this drawing.

Beneath this pen-and-ink drawing there is a faint graphite pencil sketch for a different composition representing only the face of Madame Matisse (see fig. 7.3 and fig. 7.4). This sketch, which fills the entire sheet, represents the sitter’s face in a position identical to that in the final drawing. Matisse abandoned this earlier sketch and drew the current composition directly in pen and ink with no preliminary marks.

The sheet was trimmed on all sides. The bottom and left edges are trimmed just up to the design without cropping the drawing. It cannot be determined whether the paper was trimmed before or after Matisse executed the work.

The multilayer interactive image viewer is designed to facilitate the viewer’s exploration and comparison of the technical images (fig. 7.5).

Signed: Henri-Matisse (lower right, in pen and black ink) (fig. 7.6).

Matisse drew using pen and black ink over traces of graphite. The ink has a slight sheen evident in raking light, which indicates the presence of a resinous binder.

The support is medium-thick, smooth, cream wove paper. It is a stiff, hard-sized paper with a smooth, compact surface that is well suited to drawing with pen. On the recto, a very fine screen pattern imparted by the paper mold is visible in strong raking light. The sheet is irregularly trimmed; the corners are not square.

49.4 × 31.2 cm (19 1/8 × 12 in.).

Examination indicates that the work has not undergone conservation treatment.

There are faint golden stains near the lower right and upper left corners. A faint brown line runs horizontally from the upper right edge; it appears to be a stray mark. There is a stray mark in the neck of the sitter.  
Kristi Dahm

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section provenance" id="provenance">Sold by the artist to Paul Rosenberg (1881–1959), Paris, by winter 1929–1959.

Estate of Paul Rosenberg, 1959–after June 23, 1964.

Sold to Dorothy Braude Edinburg (c. 1921–Jan. 5, 2015), after June 23, 1964–Jan. 11, 1999.

Partially given to the Art Institute of Chicago, Jan. 11, 1999.

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section exhibitions" id="exhibitions">Possibly Paris, Chez Paul Rosenberg, Exposition d’œuvres de quelques peintres du XXe siècle, May–June 1927, cat. 30, as Femme assise.

New York, Paul Rosenberg and Company, 19th and 20th Century French Drawings and Watercolors, Feb. 4–Mar. 2, 1963, cat. 19, as Seated Woman in Armchair, 1914.

Wellesley [MA] College Art Museum, Two Women Collect, Apr. 2–25, 1976, no cat.

Wellesley [MA] College Art Museum, One Century: Wellesley Families Collect; An Exhibition Celebrating the Centennial of Wellesley College, Apr. 15–May 30, 1978, cat. 46 (ill.), as Seated Woman, 1906–08.

Boston, Institute of Contemporary Art, Twentieth Century Drawings from Massachusetts Collections, July 10–Sept. 2, 1979, exhibition brochure, no cat. no., as Femme Assise avec un Eventail (Madame Matisse), ca. 1906.

Boston, Museum of Fine Arts, The Modern Tradition: Twentieth Century Drawings and Watercolors, Jan. 26–June 22, 1980, no cat.

Art Institute of Chicago, Drawn to Form: Modern Drawings from Dorothy Braude Edinburg to the Harry B. and Bessie K. Braude Memorial Collection in the Art Institute of Chicago, June 11–Sept. 7, 1999, exhibition brochure, cat. 33, as Mme Matisse with a Fan, 1906.

Dusseldorf, K20 Kunstsammlung Nordrhein-Westfalen, Henri Matisse: Figur, Farbe, Raum, Oct. 29, 2005–Feb. 19, 2006, cat. 44 (ill.), as Madame Matisse à l’éventail/Madame Matisse mit Fächer, 1905/1906; Basel, Foundation Beyeler, Mar. 19–July 9, 2006.

Art Institute of Chicago, Drawings in Dialogue: Old Master through Modern, The Harry B. and Bessie K. Braude Memorial Collection, June 3–July 30, 2006, cat. 140 (ill.), as Madame Matisse with Her Fan, 1906.

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section references" id="references">Paul Rosenberg, Exposition d’œuvres de quelques peintres du XXe siècle, exh. cat. (Paul Rosenberg, 1927), p. 6, cat. 30, as Femme assise.

Paul Rosenberg and Company, 19th and 20th Century French Drawings and Watercolors, exh. cat. (Paul Rosenberg & Co., 1963), cat. 19, as Seated Woman in Armchair, 1914.

Ann Gabhart, Judith Hoos Fox, and Elisabeth Thresher Scharlack, One Century: Wellesley Families Collect; An Exhibition Celebrating the Centennial of Wellesley College, exh. cat. (Wellesley College Museum, 1978), cat. 46 (ill.), as Seated Woman, 1906–08.

Twentieth Century Drawings from Massachusetts Collections, exh. brochure, with a foreword by Elisabeth Sussman (Institute of Contemporary Art, 1979), n.pag., as Femme Assise avec un Eventail (Madame Matisse), c. 1906.

John Elderfield, The Drawings of Henri Matisse, exh. cat. (Arts Council of Great Britain/Museum of Modern Art, New York/Thames & Hudson, 1984), pp. 37, fig. 5 (ill.); 283, no. 5; 301, n. 82, as Seated Woman, 1905.

Anita Hopmans, De onbekende Van Dongen: Vroege en Fauvistische tekeningen 1895–1912, exh. cat. (Boijmans Van Beuningen Museum Rotterdam, 1996), p. 208 (ill.), as Madame Matisse en robe japonaise, 1905.

Jay A. Clarke, Drawn to Form: Modern Drawings from Dorothy Braude Edinburg to the Harry B. and Bessie K. Braude Memorial Collection in the Art Institute of Chicago, exhibition brochure (Art Institute of Chicago, 1999), cat. 33, as Mme Matisse with a Fan, 1906.

“Verzeichnis der Werke,” in Henri Matisse: Figur Farbe Raum, exh. cat., ed. Pia Müller-Tamm (K20 Kunstsammlung Nordrhein-Westfalen/Hatje Cantz, 2005), p. 373, cat. 44, as Madame Matisse à l’éventail/Madame Matisse mit Fächer, 1905/1906. Translated as “List of Works,” in Henri Matisse: Figure Color Space, exh. cat., ed. Pia Müller-Tamm (K20 Kunstsammlung Nordrhein-Westfalen/Hatje Cantz, 2005), p. 373, cat. 44, as Madame Matisse à l’éventail/Madame Matisse with Her Fan, 1905/06.

Maria Müller, “Gemälde, Plastiken, Zeichnungen, Grafiken, Papierschnitte: Von innen nach außen,” in Henri Matisse: Figur Farbe Raum, exh. cat., ed. Pia Müller-Tamm (K20 Kunstsammlung Nordrhein-Westfalen/Hatje Cantz, 2005), p. 132, pl. 44, as Madame Matisse à l’éventail/Madame Matisse mit Fächer, 1905/1906. Translated by Steven Lindberg as “Paintings, Sculptures, Drawings, Prints, Paper Cutouts: From Inside to Outside,” in Henri Matisse: Figure Color Space, exh. cat., ed. Pia Müller-Tamm (K20 Kunstsammlung Nordrhein-Westfalen/Hatje Cantz, 2005), p. 132, pl. 44, as Madame Matisse à l’éventail/Madame Matisse with Her Fan, 1905/06.

Margret Stuffmann, “Henri Matisse: Zeichnen–ohne Ende,” in Henri Matisse: Figur Farbe Raum, exh. cat., ed. Pia Müller-Tamm (K20 Kunstsammlung Nordrhein-Westfalen/Hatje Cantz, 2005), p. 49, as Madame Matisse à l’éventail. Translated by Steven Lindberg as “Henri Matisse: Drawing—without End,” in Henri Matisse: Figure Color Space, exh. cat., ed. Pia Müller-Tamm (K20 Kunstsammlung Nordrhein-Westfalen/Hatje Cantz, 2005), p. 49, as Madame Matisse à l’éventail.

Suzanne Folds McCullagh, ed., Drawings in Dialogue: Old Master through Modern; The Harry B. and Bessie K. Braude Memorial Collection, with contributions by Douglas Druick, Brandon Ruud et al. (Art Institute of Chicago/Yale University Press, 2006), pp. 15; 146; 191, cat. 140 (ill.), as Madame Matisse with Her Fan, 1906.

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section other_documentation" id="other_documentation">Number  
Location: lower right  
Method: pen and brown ink  
Content: Inv. No. 935 (fig. 7.7)

The media and their application, as well as the condition of the artwork, were assessed through visual examination using normal, transmitted, and raking light; microscope magnification (80–300×); and ultraviolet-light examination (254 and 365 nm). Infrared reflectography was performed with a Sinar 86H digital back (without an infrared filter) with a Heliopan ES 58 RG 830 cutoff filter at a 1 second exposure.

</section><section epub:type="footnotes" id="footnotes">The work has had the following titles:

Feb. 1963: Seated Woman in Armchair (Paul Rosenberg & Co., 19th and 20th Century French Drawings and Watercolors, exh. cat. [Paul Rosenberg & Co., 1963], n.pag., cat. 19.)

Apr. 1978: Seated Woman (Ann Gabhart, Judith Hoos Fox, and Elisabeth Thresher Scharlack, One Century: Wellesley Families Collect; An Exhibition Celebrating the Centennial of Wellesley College, exh. cat. [Wellesley College Museum, 1978], n.pag., cat. 46 [ill.].)

July 1979: Femme Assise avec un Eventail (Madame Matisse) (Institute of Contemporary Art, Twentieth Century Drawings from Massachusetts Collections, exhibition brochure [Institute of Contemporary Art, 1979], n.pag.)

1984: Seated Woman (John Elderfield, The Drawings of Henri Matisse, exh. cat. [Arts Council of Great Britain/Museum of Modern Art, New York/Thames & Hudson, 1984], p. 37, fig. 5 [ill.]; p. 283, no. 5; p. 301n82.)

1996: Madame Matisse en robe japonaise (Anita Hopmans, De onbekende Van Dongen: Vroege en Fauvistische tekeningen 1895–1912, exh. cat. [Museum Boijmans Van Beuningen, 1996], p. 208 [ill.])

June 1999: Mme Matisse with a Fan (Jay A. Clarke, Drawn to Form: Modern Drawings from Dorothy Braude Edinburg to the Harry B. and Bessie K. Braude Memorial Collection in the Art Institute of Chicago, exhibition brochure [Art Institute of Chicago, 1999], n.pag., cat. 33.)

2005: Madame Matisse à l’éventail (Margret Stuffmann, “Henri Matisse: Zeichnen–ohne Ende,” in Henri Matisse: Figur, Farbe, Raum, exh. cat., ed. Pia Müller-Tamm [Hatje Cantz, 2005], p. 49, cat. 44.)

Oct. 2005: Madame Matisse à l’éventail/Madame Matisse mit Fächer (Melanie Horst, “Gemälde, Plastiken, Zeichnungen, Grafiken, Papierschnitte” and “Verzeichnis der Werke,” both in Müller-Tamm, Henri Matisse, p. 132, pl. 44; p. 72, cat. 44.)

The work has been variously dated:

Feb. 1963: 1914 (Rosenberg & Co., 19th and 20th Century French Drawings and Watercolors, cat. 19.)

Apr. 1978: 1906–08 (Gabhart, Fox, and Scharlack, One Century, n.pag., cat. 46 [ill.].)

July 1979: ca. 1906 (Institute of Contemporary Art, Twentieth Century Drawings from Massachusetts Collections, n.pag.)

1984: 1905 (Elderfield, Drawings of Henri Matisse, p. 37, fig. 5 [ill.]; p. 283, no. 5; p. 301n82.)

1996: 1905 (Hopmans, De onbekende Van Dongen, p. 208 [ill.])

Oct. 2005: 1905/06 (Horst, “Gemälde, Plastiken, Zeichnungen, Grafiken, Papierschnitte” and “Verzeichnis der Werke,” p. 132, pl. 44; p. 372, cat. 44.]

June 1999: 1906 (Clarke, Drawn to Form: Modern Drawings from Dorothy Braude Edinburg to the Harry B. and Bessie K. Braude Memorial Collection in the Art Institute of Chicago, n.pag., cat. 33.)

Using the toolbar at the bottom right, any two images of the painting may be selected for comparison by clicking the layers icon to the right of the slider bar. The slider bar may be moved to transition back and forth between the two chosen images. The jagged-line icon brings up a list of available annotations, or colored lines that show the significant features visible in each image, which may be turned on or off in any combination. For example, the red annotation lines, associated with the natural-light image, trace some of the painting’s key compositional features. When overlaid onto a technical image (X-ray, raking light, ultraviolet, etc.), the red outlines help the viewer to better observe how features in the technical image relate to or diverge from the painting as seen with the naked eye. (When annotations are turned on, a legend appears in the upper right showing each color and its associated image type.) The circular-arrow icon returns the image to the default settings (natural light, full-image view, natural-light [red] annotation on). The four-arrow icon toggles between the view of the image in the page and a full-screen view of the image. In the upper right corner, the vertical slider bar may be moved to zoom in or out of the image; different parts of the image can be accessed by clicking and dragging within the image itself. The icon in the upper left corner opens a small view of the full image, within which a red box indicates the portion of the overall image being viewed when zooming is enabled.

Descriptions of paper thickness and texture follow the standard set forth in Elizabeth Lunning and Roy Perkinson, The Print Council of America Paper Sample Book: A Practical Guide to the Description of Paper (Print Council of America/Sun Hill, 1996).

Ilda François, Paul Rosenberg and Company, to James Glisson, email, June 7, 2011; photocopy in curatorial object file, Department of Prints and Drawings, Art Institute of Chicago. Invoice of Mar. 4, 1964, from Paul Rosenberg and Company to Dorothy Braude Edinburg states that Rosenberg acquired the drawing from the artist; photocopy in curatorial object file, Department of Prints and Drawings, Art Institute of Chicago.

François to James Glisson, email, June 7, 2011, and invoice for partial payment from Paul Rosenberg and Company to Dorothy Braude Edinburg, June 23, 1964; photocopies in curatorial object file, Department of Prints and Drawings, Art Institute of Chicago.

Invoice for partial payment from Paul Rosenberg and Company to Dorothy Braude Edinburg, June 23, 1964, and Board of Trustees meeting minutes, Jan. 11, 1999, p. 2; photocopies in curatorial object file, Department of Prints and Drawings, Art Institute of Chicago.

Board of Trustees meeting minutes, Jan. 11, 1999, p. 2; photocopy in curatorial object file, Department of Prints and Drawings, Art Institute of Chicago.

According to Jane Callahan, archivist at Wellesley College, no catalogue exists for this exhibition. Madame Matisse with Her Fan appears on temporary receipt no. 1268, dated March 23, 1976, as no. 9, Portrait of Mme. Matisse; photocopy in curatorial object file, Department of Prints and Drawings, Art Institute of Chicago.

Femme assise could be Madame Matisse with Her Fan: the title is similar to the one used by Rosenberg for this work in 1963, but the description is extremely general and does not include a date or measurements.

Catalogue for the exhibition The Sculpture and Drawings of Henri Matisse, organized by the Arts Council of Great Britain with the collaboration of the Museum of Modern Art, New York. The exhibition was held at the Hayward Gallery, London, Oct. 4, 1984–Jan. 6, 1985, and the Museum of Modern Art, Feb. 27–May 14, 1985. Madame Matisse with Her Fan was not in the exhibition.

Not in exhibition.
